title: Great Company
pros: WLB is good, smart people
cons: Nothing that comes to mind

title: Thank you NVIDIA and CEO Huang
pros: The opportunities to forge a career path that aligned to my interests and talents along with the supportive culture.  The benefits afforded to employees are second to none.  Being a part of this organization since the launch of DGX in 2016 has been very fulfilling and incredibility rewarding.
cons: Sales overall at NVIDIA are often treated as second class citizens instead of professional assets - this is especially the case, unfortunately, in our Healthcare organization.  Too often we are tasked with to do's while not being any part of the discussions on what to do or why.
advice_to_management: At some point customers will not knock on our door as often as they do today.  Upskilling our technical team members on how to ask questions, versus dispensing advice, the importance of be inquisitive instead of teachers, could better prepare for that day.

title: Think twice if you’re a parent
pros: Great leadership, product, vision. Kind, hard working people.
cons:
Horrible place to work for parents. Apply elsewhere if you want to spend the holidays with your kids. Plan on working nights & weekends regularly (all the time when you don’t have childcare). There’s no onsite gym or any daycare options…definitely missing the benefits of a big tech company. Quarterly “free days” are almost never free—just frustrating if you’ve planned something fun, that you can no longer do.  

Very volatile and hard to predict when your weekend will blow up…which leads to constant anxiety.
advice_to_management: If you’d like to attract and maintain a diverse workforce that includes working parents, consider adding benefits that make it easier, not harder to thrive at your company. If you don’t care about attracting parents, then I’d continue doing what you’re doing.

title: CEO is a rock star, company encourages collaboration
pros: It is a rare company that encourages collaboration across teams. The first principle thinking is encouraged from the top.
cons: Slow climb on career ladder. If you are seeking to cimb up the ladder fast, NVIDIA might not be the ideal place.

title: Good company overall, but a lot depends on the team. Great work/life balance. Compensation and bureaucracy issues.
pros: You can meet great collegues and if you are lucky with management you can have a freedom to work on the topics you consider interesting and important with little pressure and change of direction every few months. Great work/life balance. And of course you can publish your work even in ML/robotics areas.
cons: Depending on the team, but bureaucracy can be quite a limiting factor. Compensation is on the lower spectrum compared to other top tier companies. If not a rate of stock price growth it would be a disaster.

title: Great place to work - Changing Rapidly - Very Demanding
pros: Cutting-edge work, great pay, great team members
cons:
Cutting-edge work - means you have to keep up with the cutting-edge.  This takes time and energetic curiosity.
Great team members - they demand you be great also - this takes time and can be challenging
advice_to_management: No advice, just a comment.  Great culture at NV, obviously culture is very important and with tremendous growth there is no way not to have a culture change. It's a conundrum.  Personally, I wouldn't work at any other company.

title: Dynamic / Lots to Learn

cons: Sometimes, the long term direction is not clear, or changes very fast. The pro of this is that engineers can have a meaningful say in direction or architecture.
advice_to_management: Prioritize lowering tech debt, building good long term systems instead of always rushing for the next deliverable.

title: Awesome Internship Experience
pros:
This is my first internship, and it's truly been an extraordinary journey. NVIDIA treats interns just like full-time employees, allowing us to genuinely participate in important projects. Beyond my team's work, there are plenty of opportunities to connect with other teams. We can even attend meetings for groups we're interested in, which shows how open-minded they are and how willing they are to let interns explore various areas. If I have any concerns about my progress or need adjustments, I can always discuss with my mentor. Both my manager and mentor consistently check on my progress and are responsive to any help I need.

There are also a lot of leisure and entertainment activities, along with numerous lectures and extra learning opportunities. They even provide shuttle bus services at designated stops, which is incredibly helpful for anyone new to California.
cons: No cons so far I could imagine.
advice_to_management: Nope

title: Culture of harassment in some orgs
pros: State of the art hardware, smart coworkers, good stock. My team is great but some are not. If you are on bad team beware
cons: Some of the most extreme harassment I have ever seen in the some of the orgs which we worked with. I know of someone who was blackmailed into spending tens of thousands on lab materials. HR did not nothing. Attrition rates can hit 30% or even higher at 70% due to management at one of the most historic stock runs of history. Some of these people walked away from 1 M+ stock packages due to extreme management harassment which includes inappropriate adult material displayed at work, physical threats from management, and extreme disfunction overall. I saw one manager have nearly an entire team quit. That manager was then promoted. They put managers in between this individual and his direct reports when he threatened to hurt one of his reportees. This should result in immediate termination. This was the worst treatment I have ever seen. Managers will deliberately strip you of equipment to force you to fail.
advice_to_management: Listen to complaints about managers and institute 360 reviews of managers. If a manager threatens to hurt employees they should be immediately terminated. We all review bombed this manager via internal channels to help a new college grad who was being actively extorted and had to liquidate major portions of their stock grant to finance lab materials at the most profitable semiconductor company in the world. HR does nothing and actively retaliates against whistleblowers in violation of federal law.
job_title: Senior Analog Mixed Signal Design Engineer

title: Probably the best company I've worked for in 30+ year career
pros:
NVIDIA walks the walk. They have standards for how people should be treated, and they live up to it. They pay very well, and have generous ESPP and 401K matching programs. They also encourage people who are interested in working on something new to move internally - that keeps your team's perspectives fresh.
One story I heard illustrates the heart of the company: I joined in the middle of the worst of the pandemic, when everything was locked down. NVIDIA has a big campus in Santa Clara, and that was likewise shut down. The company that provided the on-site food for employees was obviously not needed, but the CEO, Jensen Huang, decide to keep paying them so that they wouldn't have to lay off their people. The money was already budgeted, so rather that treat it as a windfall for NVIDIA, he made sure that the people from the catering service could still make their mortgage payments and support their families. Now that's a company I could be proud to work for!
cons: Health insurance: unless you're in California, the coverage options are limited to Cigna, and none of my doctors accepted Cigna.
advice_to_management: I only had one bad manager: someone who would promise something and then never follow through. When I mentioned that to someone else in the org, they just said "yeah,  is like that - can't rely on anything he says". But for some reason that guy kept his job despite bad behavior. I had wished there was some way to initiate a review from above where people who worked with  the problematic person could give anonymous feedback to confirm or refute the problem.

title: good
pros: pretty good, working with top enginner in the world
cons:
It's not easy starting out as a new employee right after graduation, especially in a fast-paced environment. Without prior experience — whether it's a PhD or a few years in the industry — it’s easy to feel overwhelmed by the expectations and complexity of the work.

That said, the same challenge can also be a great opportunity. If you're a well-trained engineer with a strong foundation, you get the chance to work alongside highly skilled professionals and grow rapidly. The steep learning curve can become your biggest advantage — if you're willing to embrace it.
advice_to_management: good

title: Great Company To Do Your "Life's Work"
pros: Very exciting environment, good work-life balance, focus on taking time for yourself. Many people are passionate about their work. Extremely collaborative environment, you can slack virtually anyone and they're usually likely to help. Overall great culture.
cons: Amenities aren't as good as some other tech companies. For example, there's no gym and, while reasonably priced ($4-$12), meals are not free on campus.

title: Fantastic Culture
pros: Great engineering culture at the cutting edge
cons: it was a great environment

title: Don't believe the hype
pros: You'll quickly be working on interesting, relevant, timely problems. The company at large seems great, but your experience is highly dependent on which area you're in. Nice benefits and perks.
cons:
Directors pitted against each other and tons of duplicative work happening -- I guess NVIDIA has the money to do that. Despite being "transparent" and "flat," everything is "talk to your manager" and you can't even find out someone's job family/major department, so it's highly hierarchical and opaque, despite what they say.

I've been warned multiple times as a relatively newer person, not to cross certain leaders or provide genuine feedback, as they will protect certain folks at all costs, whether you mean well or not.

Folks in my area work 4-8 hour days on the weekends and regularly work late at night and early in the morning, outside usual working hours for their timezone.
advice_to_management: Do more listening further across the stack. Reward folks who run their department/org humanely, not just if they get things done at all costs. Discourage how much folks are working out of hours and on the weekends.

title: Amazing place to work

Quite the opposite actually, coming to work is a highlight because I get to work with so many great team members.
cons: It's a dynamic environment, so things change a lot and all the time and there is always more to do than there is time to do it in. Doesn't really bother me though.

title: My experience @ NVIDIA
pros: Flat organization, outstanding collaboration between teams, priorities are clear, very little politics. The company truly cares about the employees and the benefits package illustrates that point.
cons: The work can be challenging (this could also be a pro) and sometimes, due to the situation, you can work a lot of extra hours. But, that is not the normal case.
